document.title: History and Social Science Framework - Massachusetts Curriculum Framework - 2018

03988DA6B38A4E7593137B8AC8640B50.description:
Analyze the events, people and conditions that have given rise to international terrorism 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for History and Social Science 161
including the emergence of the global terror network Al-Qaeda, the Taliban in Afghanistan, and
ISIS, and evaluate responses by governments and societies to international terrorist activity

ABC4A9C4CD164CA3B22ED748BF767E82.description: the treatment of Rohingya people in Myanmar

42A0AA140699404CBECD4AB7CE0F0B67.description: conflict between Shi’a and Sunni Muslims

EE40214361F64B2AA761ACDE40DF5DFA.description: mass atrocities in Guatemala and Syria

EBBBCD3A1A56413BAAA55D2BB3C17670.description: conflict between India and Pakistan in Kashmir

1EB6A435A1534903BECF7F0198D788DB.description: the Darfur crisis and South Sudan

68030E36CE46461491AEF62DCD41872F.description: the Rwandan Genocide and ethnic conflicts in the Democratic Republic of Congo

F6F63470ADB442F080D963D02ECF391C.description: the Cambodian genocide carried out by the Khmer Rouge

DF5F49BD40BB4D56BDB1CFC0CE729265.description: the Bosnian War and the persecution of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo

AE2FD4C41C6D4BCC8317B9C120715C48.description: conflict between Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland

8B16E8BC4F36455B9B865F8C7B9CC349.description:
Distinguish between the concepts of genocide and mass atrocity and analyze the causes of
genocide and mass atrocities in the modern world (e.g., conflicts over political power, historical
grievances, manipulation of ideas about difference and fear by political forces). Students may
use one the following events to address this standard:

94E1B5B2EB0C479F8443DC79C22FE006.description:
The politics of difference among people: conflicts,
genocide, and terrorism

32A5FE4ADE364C44AFF887741F73DD86.description:
humanitarian efforts to slow the spread of the Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome
(AIDS), lower rates of disease and childhood mortality, provide solutions to recurring
refugee crises, increase the availability of education for girls and women, and develop
local rural economies

8C5950A8820D4FC88DFE3F7D6A09B1CF.description:
environmental efforts to slow climate change, preserve wildlife habitat, and increase
agricultural production

814F69F66AEF4A98A83DDD64FA7D73A1.description: Evaluate the impact of international efforts to address global issues.

2CA8983AE270453D849E2B6FE7686DBD.description:
Analyze the rise in political and economic power of China and its increasingly critical role in
global affairs (e.g., North Korea, the World Trade Organization)

088E33C0EB4A4384A5D6737C9C3F4E33.description:
Explain the role of populist political movements, their strength in European political parties in
the early 21st century

09B85E7D3536416AA417B1CB44D535CC.description:
Analyze the major forces in the Middle East since 1980, including the rise of Islamic
fundamentalism; the bulge in the youth population, rivalry between Saudi Arabia and Iran,
struggle for autonomy by the Kurds, the political challenges of the oil-rich Persian Gulf states,
the Iranian Revolution of 1978–1979 and the Iran-Iraq War, the Persian Gulf War, the Iraq
War, Arab uprisings, the growth of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS).

DEEADA25929D443B93C5CC8D44C81FA3.description:
Analyze reasons for globalization – an international network of economic systems—and
explain its consequences for workers in highly developed and less developed countries.

9A54E25B7E1944D8A50A0D8FEABAA19D.description:
Analyze how various social and intellectual movements of the second half of the 20th
century changed traditional assumptions about race, ethnicity, class, gender, the
environment, and religion (e.g., the modern feminist movement, the LGBTQ rights
movement; the environmentalist movement and emergence of Green parties).

528EEFA87DEE4C13AF186194CA2A4263.description: Jane Goodall and the study of primates and ecology

17F3D742200443DA9C0B11661A816B2B.description: The invention of the ARPAnet and its evolution into the Internet

B50DE02D47C3455EB77BCC8C849AE970.description: The development of the first integrated circuit in 1958

B4CF8127B462426CBC546A9584EAB8C5.description:
Rosalind Franklin, Maurice Wilkins, James Watson and Francis Crick, the
discovery of DNA, and the Human Genome Project

782E8690DCBB4982856C509C8E546CE4.description: Jonas Salk, the polio vaccine, and other medical breakthroughs

AB40D7C197A743D9AD1D64DF938F3F65.description: Wernher von Braun and space exploration

6600906EC43049978C66042D24A52E43.description: Enrico Fermi, J. Robert Oppenheimer, Edward Teller, and nuclear energy

943A179A90BF42BD9CD25E2E81E186F0.description: Marie and Pierre Curie and radioactivityg

455A1E01592D4A2E839F7BFB9E69147F.description: Albert Einstein and the theory of relativity

C1B02E3682FB43FB955B1A04AD3F4207.description:
Evaluate how scientific developments of the 20th century altered understanding of the natural
world, changed the lives of the general populace, and led to further scientific research.
Students may use one of the following examples to address this standard:

CB3A8E4034E54A8BAEA3020DD78C6119.description:
Analyze the contributing factors to and the effects of the global surge in economic
productivity, the rise in living standards in Western Europe and Japan, such as the long
postwar peace between democratic nations, the role of migrant workers in rebuilding postwar
nations, and the policies of international economic organizations

AF3F5A60E2FD4A65A0F2545B11640496.description:
Evaluate the consequences of the breakup of the Soviet Union on the development of market
economies, political and social stability, the spread of nuclear technology and other
technologies of mass destruction to rogue states and terrorist organizations, and analyze how
these consequences led to the consolidation of political power in the hands of an oligarchy
during the first and second decades of the 21st century

9F416AF79FBC4DBBB06A2786319FA17A.description: the Russian opposition movement to Boris Yeltsin

6A4A730E1DD2464A9D31494C75B86EE7.description: Mikhail Gorbachev’s leadership and policies of glasnost and perestroika

F738FD2CC09B460C87249C72CD6C7818.description: the fall of the Berlin Wall

C3DC8B0679D8433CAFB186C905A842B8.description: the rise of nationalist sentiment in the Soviet bloc and USSR

78841EF0AF144DA88D10D70F759A6738.description:
The deployment of intermediate range nuclear missiles in Europe and the
Reagan Administration’s investment in new defense technologies and the
expansion of U.S. military forces

468DC275709743808A228D54FB316A8B.description:
The 1975 Helsinki Accords and the emergence of human rights movements in
Eastern Europe

2115D7179A96413B8FA5852D8904D797.description:
Analyze the causes for the decline and collapse of the Soviet Union and the communist
regimes of Eastern Europe, including the increasingly costly geopolitical competition with the
United States, the growing gap between the economies of Western and Eastern Europe, the
impact on people’s lives of the weakness of the Soviet economy, the toll of extended military
conflict in Afghanistan, and the weakening popular support for communism in the Soviet
Union and Eastern Europe.

244BFD767BA14EA1AA6D2A85312733A9.description:
attempts to secure peace between Palestinians and Israelis, including the
proposal of a two-state solution

C73D98B51BBD4832B92468B48D1820D3.description:
the diverse mix of cultures (e.g., Jews, Palestinians, and Arabs of Christian,
Jewish, Muslim, and Druze backgrounds) in the region in the late 20th and early
21st centuries

7394C87AEF74467EA1D2062FF7B79778.description:
the various wars between Israel and neighboring Arab states since 1947, (e.g.,
the Six Day War and the Yom Kippur War)

DFCEFA7733D5458BA706DA2C61DD8E0D.description:
the rejection of surrounding Arab countries of the UN decision and the invasion
of Israel by Arab countries

0FD9DB7C67B74240B75091EB78CB8E52.description: Palestinian loss of land and the creation of refugees by Israeli military action

C2ABBB0F406843DBA96CB2634730ABF5.description:
the United Nations (UN) vote in 1947 to partition the western part of the
Palestine Mandate into two independent countries

65A6651B9561471087DFD786A69F2990.description:
the growth of Zionism, and 19th and early 20th century immigration by Eastern
European Jews to Palestine

ADFF34EF60E3415A86C44B0C77CCD6DB.description:
Explain the background for the establishment of the modern state of Israel in 1948, and
subsequent military and political conflicts

CB4076FE88EE4C9EB7EAAFA13A06CC36.description:
Explain the defense of and resistance to the official South African government policy of
apartheid (legalized racial segregation) between 1948 and 1991, and analyze how opposition
by the African National Congress, including resistance leader Nelson Mandela, and
international organizations such as the United Nations, contributed to the downfall of
apartheid

B777FD9BA9B14E6D9B7DD39E34DD2C21.description:
Analyze the development and goals of nationalist movements in Africa, Asia, Central and 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for History and Social Science 158
South America, and the Middle East, and evaluate how one of these movements and its leader
brought about decolonization and independence in the second half of the 20th century (e.g.,
Fidel Castro in Cuba, Patrice Lumumba in Congo, Ho Chi Minh in Vietnam, Gamel Abdul Nasser
in Egypt, Jawaharlal Nehru in India, Salvador Allende in Chile).

6423CE4E0EE44F478B120D1F8A38859A.description:
Analyze the major developments in Chinese history during the second half of the 20th century,
including the Chinese Civil War and the triumph of the Communist Revolution in China, the
rise of Mao Tse-Tung and political, social, and economic upheavals under his leadership, such
as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution, the Tiananmen Square student
protests in Beijing in 1989 and economic reforms under the leadership of Deng Xiaoping.

FEBF09C5DA7B42648A11FB722998A2D1.description: détente and diplomatic efforts between the USSR and the West

AE6F5FD206BD43D68A5BF67E60D1BF9A.description: the arms race and arms control agreements (including the ABM and SALT treaties)

6843EAC431F1459593BED8F1A6246082.description: The Cuban Revolution and the Cuban Missile Crisis

0FFA8238DEFD42C99DC94B12D92986C7.description: Soviet-U.S. competition in the Middle East and the Soviet War in Afghanistan

6204C8EBF3F14A548ACA018A6134D168.description:
the United States backing for the overthrow of Mossadegh in Iran (1953) and Arbenz in
Guatemala (1954), demonstrating the stakes of the Cold War in non-Great Power
countries

A0A88C07440243E5966C2EB227DAAE27.description:
life in the USSR after Stalin’s death in 1953, the rule of Nikita Khrushchev, popular
uprisings in Soviet-controlled countries such as the 1956 uprising in Hungary and the
“Prague Spring” of 1968

3146AB9DFDB14E10949CB5B88F1BBB27.description: the emergence of the People’s Republic of China as a major power

3A69E09A8F9747A2A2D5BC5E43E7A025.description: the policy of containment and its relation to the Korean War and the Vietnam War

E02BD93DC45B4E8EB61EA97D89F5C136.description: The Marshall Plan and the revival of Western Europe’s economy

CAA0DCE03ACF4BE28AC345D3CB2EA010.description: The partition of Germany and the Berlin Crises of 1948 and 1961

2862D35569D84D0C852E0B1EF62BEFDB.description:
Evaluate the importance of key military and political developments on the outcome of the
Cold War. Students may use one the following examples to address this standard.

922AC4DC559240DF8D4AC794AE047536.description:
Analyze the impact of transnational organizations and alliances such as the United Nations
(UN), the European Economic Community (EEC), the North Atlantic Treaty Organization
(NATO, 1949), the Warsaw Pact (1955), and the non-alignment movement on the
developments of the Cold War

D0AB1C810CB54A86BD890701204AB2FB.description:
Identify the differences in worldview between the United States and the Union of Soviet
Socialist Republics (USSR) and analyze how tensions between the USSR and the West led to
the division of Europe

414BD163DEC2404598B16F4D78C99AA2.description: the establishment of the United Nations in 1945, the promulgation of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the adoption of the Nuremberg Principles to guide the Nuremberg Tribunal of 1945 and the expansion of the Geneva Conventions in 1949

EC127212F637435BA42A66EB019A51D5.description: the nuclear arms race between the U.S and the Soviet Union

65D48F7DC8364F5C8DCCBACB23AEE562.description: the emergence of the U.S. and the Soviet Union as the world’s two superpowers

E98E4781859342FAA01C523EF0E0F6C6.description: support in Europe for political reform and decolonization

17C9BA17B88E4208B53674B71394F6E7.description:
enormous disruption of societies and the deaths of millions of soldiers, civilians, colonial
subjects, political opponents, and ethnic minorities

948A8B00237A4CA989CC06D68EFD7458.description: the physical and economic destruction through the bombing of population centers

041F05671A214C828712BB44F77A6E13.description: Evaluate the global political, economic, and social consequences of World War II

A1D59CC67EE145BCA7E502202E0957ED.description:
Analyze the decision of the United States to drop atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in
order to bring the war with Japan to a swift conclusion and its impact on relations with the
Soviet Union.

BB93556130F4469C92D185E8994DC528.description:
Describe the Holocaust, including its roots in Christian anti-Semitism, 19th century ideas about
race and nation, and the Nazi dehumanization and planned extermination of the Jews and
persecution of LGBT and Gypsy/Roma people.

C74A4D7B044149AF87E315C1A0EFDC79.description:
Identify the goals, leadership, strategies, and post-war plans of the Allied leaders (i.e., Winston
Churchill, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Joseph Stalin) and how wartime diplomacy affected the
outcome of the war and the emergence of the Cold War.

2134C85CA5984F81975E67597EC1982F.description:
Analyze the effects of one of the battles of World War II on the outcome of the war and the
countries involved:
1940: the Battles of Britain and Dunkirk;
1941: the attack on Pearl Harbor
1942: the Battles of Midway and, Corregidor
1943: Stalingrad and the Allied invasion of Italy
1944–1945: the invasion of Normandy, D-Day, the Battle of the Bulge, Battle of Berlin, Battle of
Bataan and the subsequent Bataan Death March, the Battles of Iwo Jima, Okinawa, Manila and
Corregidor

2700913C5A63407499C46937C0C4F4D4.description:
Germany’s militarization of the Rhineland, annexation of Austria, and aggression
against Czechoslovakia, the Nazi-Soviet Pact of 1939, the German attack on Poland,
and the changing responses of Great Britain and the United States to Hitler’s
strategies

BEA2F16EFB354E779D1FB356205EA3E9.description:
the Japanese invasion of China (1931), the Manchukuo State and the Nanjing
Massacre (1937), and the Japanese invasion of the Philippines (1941–42)

3DCA94B846C244D2B4C175950AD60611.description:
Analyze the aggression of Germany, Italy, and Japan in the 1930s and early 1940s and the lack of
response by the League of Nations and Western democracies.

8E74BE248F034DA2A65F3AB59DEF2447.description:
Students should analyze the following examples of how each dictator repressed
dissension and persecuted minorities:
a. the arrest and execution of political opponents to Mussolini in Italy
b. censorship of the press and propaganda
c. the Nazi use of art as propaganda, promoting classicism and disparaging
modernism as degenerate
d. the great purges under Stalin, the development and maintenance of the gulag
system, and it impact on Soviet society
e. the policy of forced collectivization in the Soviet Union and the resultant forced
famine genocide of the Ukrainian people, known as the Holodomor.
f. the Enabling Act, Night of the Long Knives, and Nuremburg Laws in Germany
g. the use of paramilitary groups and youth movements

8B916E33BEC347F9A50BE369FAE65D14.description:
Clarification Statements: Students may examine the following examples of conditions
leading to the rise of dictators to address this standard:
a. the lingering resentment over World War I and the Treaty of Versailles
b. the devastation of the Great Depression and the inability of fragile democracies
to address those effects
c. the rise of anti-Semitism and racist ideologies in Europe during the last decades
of 19th and early 20th centuries

EC7C3C41FE2D4B6F8C608CBE30A6164F.description:
Evaluate the economic, social, and political conditions that allowed the rise of Hitler, Mussolini,
and Stalin in their respective countries, and how each dictator repressed dissention and
persecuted minorities.

FC67B63EBFA340D9A537EBD9404D2AFD.description:
Identify the characteristics of fascism and totalitarianism as exhibited in the rise of the
authoritarian regimes in Italy, Germany, and the Soviet Union during the 1920s and 1930s

3B5C1070A53547FFA99E41BE5363639A.description:
the influence of the ideas of John Maynard Keynes, Ludwig von Mises, Friedrich von
Hayek, and Milton Friedman

ED203D4A565E4FC6B984B0B22089AB0F.description: political instability in weak democracies such as Germany

DCA827C65C32465EBE3F7658A03A1BDC.description:
Identify the various causes and consequences of the global economic collapse of the 1930s
and evaluate how governments responded to the effects of the Great Depression.

7D0F1A810170438794D309CB748E6D99.description:
Analyze later developments in Russian history, including the creation of the Union of Soviet 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for History and Social Science 155
Socialist Republics (USSR) in 1922, the New Economic Plan (NEP) and the creation of a Soviet
economy, artistic and cultural experimentation, the death of Lenin and the cult of his
personality, and the power struggle that resulted in Stalin’s leadership

83F829EA2BFD461385B8E1A6731A02B6.description:
Analyze the various developments of early 20th century Russian history including the Russian
Revolution within the context of World War I, the growing political and social unrest under
Czar Nicholas II, the emergence of the Bolshevik movement, the political revolutions of 1917,
and the Russian Civil War

AD115CD997F944ADAF9F628D02EE4CBC.description:
Evaluate the negotiation of the Treaty of Versailles and how the treaty did or did not address
the various issues caused by World War I

72042BAC75D84857983BA5F5A4E62D39.description:
the development of modernism in the arts, in the works by composers, visual
artists, writers, choreographers, and playwrights such as Igor Stravinsky, Pablo
Picasso, Max Ernst, René Magritte, James Joyce, Gertrude Stein, Virginia Woolf, Ruth
St. Denis, Martha Graham, Bertolt Brecht, Luigi Pirandello

CAE93427D8CD43A681A922A42E709CD6.description: the proceedings of the Paris Peace Conference and the Treaty of Versailles

1C5471BFA18A4C2DADD90CAD822FE91B.description:
the establishment of European mandates in the Middle East and the creation of
modern state boundaries in the region

5769C67E00324100A1758E81F0E6AFD0.description: the modernization of Turkey under President Kemal Atatürk

FAEA75570C554FCAB1E8C10014A84E3B.description: the collapse of the Russian, Ottoman, and Austrian Empires

0BEF340405E04BDFB9F9D755A2AEE7FA.description: the emergence of a “Lost Generation” in European countries

ED7C203BCE54421E8B992B776670C427.description: the vast economic destruction resulting from the war

00E5DB5EF4334F8E91970CB04C41A3C7.description: Analyze the political, social, economic, and cultural developments following World War I.

D7A4B8E677294AC18FECE96C143D9EBC.description:
the impact of war on the home front in Europe, including the conscription, war
propaganda, rationing, and government control of wartime industries

02369415D3B543069540928153ABB157.description:
the expansion of World War I beyond Europe into a global conflict (including the
mobilization of Asian and African colonial subjects as troops to support military
efforts and the reasoning for and impact of United States involvement; the impact
on various nationalities, religious and ethnic groups)

C0A28C48577C4320A9FC92400953582F.description:
the use of industrial weapons and prolonged trench warfare and how they led to
massive casualties and loss of life

796B2D017AE8413683C5AFFAB4B23B1A.description:
Evaluate the ways in which World War I was a total war and its impact on the warring countries
and beyond

118D32D409C14A07AE78B8A5E0478759.description:
Analyze the factors that led to the outbreak of World War I (e.g., the emergence of Germany as
a great power, the rise of nationalism and weakening of multinational empires, industrial and
colonial competition, militarism, and Europe’s complex alliance systems

DEE054C66EE04BF18372F6872AF86B0B.description:
colonialism portrayed in literature and journalism by writers such as Rudyard
Kipling, Edward. D. Morel, Joseph Conrad, Robert Louis Stevenson, and Isak
Dinesen (Karen Blixen)

5FBD2802B5204FB08CDFB755FCABE949.description:
the influence of Japanese and African art on European art styles of
impressionism and cubism

2DEBF9B15F49424384379B3B840B6734.description:
collections of art and artifacts from around the world exhibited in international
expositions and museums

6E05F1D972844B2AAF019299CED3B9F9.description: emerging academic fields of archaeology and cultural anthropology

5D4660A2EFDB4D4988FAB7487FB16CC5.description: the introduction of new foods into Europe and the United States

E2771CC4682A4D60B7959BB40EB0BE9F.description: Asian furniture, porcelain, and cloth made for export

EB3D5025A36F431FB94A93B4E94B15FA.description:
Analyze the cultural impact of colonial encounters and trade on people in Western nations,
drawing on examples such as

3DF07B1BF4994324824B342FFE995AAF.description:
Latin America
a. Spanish control of Cuba and Puerto Rico; Portuguese colonial rule in Brazil
b. the drive by the United States to annex Mexico’s northern territories, the Dominican
Republic, Nicaragua, Cuba, and other Caribbean territories
c. the Spanish-American War of 1898

572D31EEDBEC4FBE999E064043E9AACD.description:
Africa
a. the impact of European direct and indirect control of the existing political structure of
African countries
b. the exploitation of African people for European economic gain in a variety of industries
c. agricultural changes and new patterns of employment
d. interactions between India and East Africa
e. the effects of assimilation on the people of Africa

96A0758730BC46C285A0B2E11270889E.description:
Japan
a. the Meiji Restoration and the opening of Japan to the West
b. the rapid modernization and industrialization of Japan
c. the emergence of a growing Japanese empire in Asia by the early 20th century

48A785D4476E47EFA1BBD0815F6D5B66.description:
China
a. the spheres of influence and extraterritorial rights for European nations
b. the role of the British East India Company in controlling the opium trade between India
and China and the impact of the opium trade on Chinese society and politics
c. the rise of anti-Western and nationalist movements during the 19th century

A429FDA93C434EC8BA6509C6D176A873.description:
India
a. the economic and political relationship between India and Britain
b. the role of the British East India Company in India
c. development of new railway infrastructure in India
d. the Indian Rebellion of 1857
e. the rise of Indian nationalism and the influence and ideas of Mahatma Gandhi in the
20th century for an independent India

2630C1BCC399495D9D671EEDA2F7B629.description:
Analyze the impact of Western imperialism in Asia, Africa, and Latin America.
Clarification Statement: In addressing Standard 18, students should gain an overall
view of what modern imperialism was and be able to relate that to their knowledge
of earlier empires from World History I.

988DE46D032A4CA094B6CB015D3F7DE4.description:
the writings of 18th and 19th century European race theorists that posited
differences among races and the superiority of the “Caucasian race” as scientific
fact, including the concept of Social Darwinism, thus justifying European attitudes
toward colonialism and slavery

D83DC0CB2D5945129476EFE4F0DA9131.description:
the integration of political, religious, and economic goals in the Spanish and
Portuguese empires in the Americas, including the conversion of indigenous peoples
by Jesuit and Franciscan missionaries, the spread of Spanish and Portuguese
languages and the imposition of European political structures.

E70E2DAF9F674EEAA2A4C9D0DE608339.description:
the importance of slavery and slave-generated capital to the Industrial Revolution;
the role of European traders, merchants, and buyers in making the slave trade
profitable in North and South America and the Caribbean Islands
Clarification Statement: Students should understand that slavery in the
Americas was an interconnected system, and that slavery did not just exist in
the Southern states of the United States (see United States History 1,
standards 20–21). They should learn that the largest number of enslaved
African men and women brought to the Americas (an estimated 4.9 million
from the 16th to the 19th century) were sold to buyers in Brazil to work on sugar
and coffee plantations and in mining.

01B0701E8084458DA18C242ACED24909.description:
competition among England, Spain, Portugal, France, the Netherlands, and Belgium
beginning in the 15th century for economic gain, resources, and strategic advantage

3BEBC914DEB344A6A406B31D23E20E74.description: Describe the causes of 19th century European global imperialism

0EC497395D8943D9A005724BA40F0729.description:
Locate on a map key locations outside of Europe controlled by the European countries in the
19th century (e.g., India, Canada, Australia, and much of Africa by Britain; the Philippines,
western and southwestern parts of North and South America, and the Caribbean Islands by
Spain; Cape Verde, Brazil, and parts of India by Portugal; North and West Africa by France;
parts of central Africa by Belgium and Germany).

5068F7C9E8DD4C9AB1E5A3EFC9338AF3.description: The global effects of 19th century imperialism

86CE778118FA4BF599C728D849535B3C.description:
Explain how industrialization spread from Great Britain to continental Europe and the United
States and how industrial development affected the political balance of power among nations.

37CE92098A4A43DAA4CCB92FD47055B5.description:
the development of government-provided social welfare programs such as
unemployment insurance and old age pensions

9937A24D977642CEB8C169E774650F2E.description:
the development of labor laws and social reform laws such as the Factory Act of
1833 and the Mines Act of 1842

E1544FA7450348538C3FE26C620F6342.description:
the expansion of suffrage for men throughout the 19th century through various
popular movements and the emergence of political liberalism, and the movement
for women’s suffrage

CFFBC9B563D04F9CB16B962E106B9E72.description:
Explain the impact of British economic and political reform movements such as labor unions on
creating political reforms during the 19th century.
Clarification Statement: Students may use

4AC21B576CA44F9B99A471A69CF5EF9C.description:
Analyze how the Industrial Revolution gave rise to new social, political, and economic
philosophies such as feminism, socialism and communism, including ideas and influence of
Robert Owen and Karl Marx.

05AF85B0A81F4A47ACEA0246BCCDA604.description:
Evaluate the economic and social impact of the Agricultural and Industrial Revolutions in
England, including population growth and the migration of workers from rural areas to new
industrial cities, the emergence of a large middle class, the growing inequity in wealth
distribution, the environmental impact of industrialization, and the harsh working and living
conditions for the urban poor.

E5E3E5E357BB4267AD4870FF9ACAB2C9.description:
the impact of Adam Smith’s economic theories and the investment of capital by
entrepreneurs on the development of new industries

83565CCB246D4998BFA9E068580F379C.description:
the expanding markets for manufactured goods in the Americas and Africa, and the
decision of China to withdraw from Indian Ocean trade, opening the way for the
British East India Company and similar trading companies of other European nations
to trade in Southeast Asia

F1AE79782C8F46A896AAD4560BDCB437.description:
the transatlantic slave trade and its role in supplying Europe with cheap raw
materials such as cotton from North American Southern states and products such as
sugar from South American and the Caribbean Islands

980D9D6743834221BA1204CF03A7C581.description:
the technological advancements of the textile, energy, and transportation industries
in the 18th and 19th centuries

89383AA2F38649BC882FCE773F6E8596.description: the presence of coal that could be relatively easily mined in Britain for use in coalfired furnaces and engines

AF291E443B0547DF890F21FC916F5597.description:
technological advancements in agricultural practices during the 18th century and 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for History and Social Science 151
their impact on productivity of farms

F2289C549CED4E298D888600A9E964D9.description:
Analyze the economic, political, social, and technological factors that led to the Agricultural
and Industrial Revolutions.

6C6C44C588C14A4287C91B44C447D4D1.description:
. The Agricultural and Industrial Revolutions in Europe
and social and political reactions in Europe

97D4B5A84390490597B6D2B370DED478.description:
the persistence of slavery in Cuba, Puerto Rico, and Brazil until the end of the 19th
century

DD385DDD0A464694AE2515D0C713134F.description:
the growing power of the United States and its economic and political impact on
Central America and the Caribbean, especially in the period before the Spanish American War of 1898

6A1617A3F8DE482A802D6D9A25A53F8E.description:
the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848 and Mexico’s resulting loss of half of its
territory to the United States

C1CB97EA304C472C827F9A16DFFB9008.description:
the 19th century wars between Liberals and Conservatives over whether to
maintain or destroy the legacies of Spanish colonialism

F6A52611BC6F49C7B72058F5AD257022.description: the role of the Catholic Church

E8BB518DF7574F9E83AB07A91A3EF381.description:
the wars for independence that led to the creation of Latin America’s modern
nation-states, including the influence and ideas of Simón Bolívar, José de San
Martin, and their connections to the Haitian, American, and French Revolutions

547495870F114D19AB109EB4C8D0ACBE.description:
Identify the major political, social, and economic developments of Central and South American
and Mexican history in the 19th century and analyze how these developments were similar to or
different from those in Europe during the same time period.

EB3740FEFFF84AF99BF5D4098C5D0A16.description:
Analyze the causes and methods of the unification of both Italy and Germany, including the
respective roles of Cavour and Bismarck, and the effect that such unification had on the
balance of power in 19th century Europe.

FB09CEA476AB4868BC3327E1CF01ED85.description:
the revolutions’ support for the ideas of popular sovereignty, religious tolerance,
and legal equality

72D10EB228704A9697D3F568D1712C70.description:
the abolition of theocratic absolutism and remaining feudal restrictions and 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for History and Social Science 150
obligations in France

847EF6A25406437DA95F9A806B0890B6.description: the revolutions’ contributions to modern nationalism

81E00A3C5F004FD4AB05EFDC63763B8C.description:
Compare the causes, goals, and outcomes of the American Revolution (1776–1787), the French
Revolution (1789-1799), and the Haitian Revolution (1791–1804), and analyze the short-term
and long-term impact of these revolutions on world history.

020EB632255940BDBFA1BBA089EC4CC1.description:
the rise and fall of Napoleon and
the French Empire (1804–1815)

7960ED1A2ECA4E9C9C8E0D037F5B6CC4.description:
Robespierre and the Reign of Terror
(c. 1793–1794)

4D12424ED00242018DA7D4CED1E3D452.description: the execution of Louis XVI in 1793

AD9BC45506D64DBCB5361AB3A8034460.description:
the storming of the Bastille on July
14, 1789 and the Declaration of the
Rights of Man and Citizen

709454D1B5C94D6A9970831D1E2B8A49.description:
the Estates General and the
National Assembly

0F0538B60D2441FC8D3736A66C183AB5.description:
Summarize the main events of the French Revolution and analyze whether the revolution
achieved its desired goals.

60D7B2D7C7C4465BB7F31784B182BC92.description:
Analyze the various political, social, intellectual, and economic causes of the French
Revolution (e.g., the influence of Enlightenment philosophy, the development of a middle
class, the excesses and growing economic struggles of the French monarchy, the
incompetence and corruption of the monarchy and government officials).

90ED36A0211740019AFD769E1E5AF24C.description:
Explain the reasons for the Glorious Revolution in England and why England was the main
exception to the growth of absolutism in royal power in Europe.

4CDA57B5A86349E9B04CE4FDC8884DDB.description:
the growing power of Russian czars, including the attempts at Westernization by
Peter the Great (1682–1785), the growth of serfdom, and Russia’s rise as an
important force in Eastern Europe and Asia; and the rise of Prussia, Poland, and
Sweden in the 17th and 18th centuries

7BC7C962A1B6413485B234CDE1C33E71.description:
the rise of the French monarchy, the policies and influence of Louis XIV (1638–
1718), and the design of the Château de Versailles as a symbol of royal power

B346B2F8B01B4DF68510808AC9D93F08.description:
the Thirty Years War in central Europe (1618–1648) and the Peace of Westphalia
(1648)

F31D72E1D53A4B9F92416F4A00646974.description:
Describe the growing consolidation of political power in Europe from 1500 to 1800 as
manifested in the rise of nation states ruled by monarchs.

8D7BD0E09D474027B462F9F27376DFF9.description:
Absolute power, political revolutions, and the growth of
nation states, c. 1700–1900

74F469C873344F8C85A0807D6A1B7645.description:
Explain the development of constitutional democracy following the American Revolution,
the United States Constitution (1787), and the Bill of Rights (1791).

F92789153FE741A4AB91ACAACDB3FC5D.description:
the English Bill of Rights and its limits on the power of the monarch to act without
the consent of Parliament

19DAD97C544F4AF18090A1CAC9ABA8FF.description:
the causes, essential events, and effects of the English Civil War and the Glorious
Revolution of 1688

E418C0DFCE0348FFB31B5D3D7C57B08C.description: Explain why England was the exception to the growth of absolutism in Europe.

A52B4F6BC3B24D03A966EDFCE4F9D061.description:
constitutional monarchy, in which a ruler is limited by a written or unwritten
constitution (e.g., English traditions beginning with Magna Carta).

8EF9C61CDA754E9A97861048572BE9F8.description:
enlightened absolutism (e.g., in Russia under Czars Peter the Great and Catherine
the Great, in which ideas of the Enlightenment temper absolutism)

F820E80F8E2C44CE87DFA50EDCBA4061.description:
absolute monarchy, in which a monarch holds unlimited power with no checks and
balances (e.g., in France of Louis XIV, Spain, Prussia, and Austria)

4960600B9CD245E5A0CE73F58E1A610E.description:
the Chinese doctrine of the Mandate of Heaven, in which a ruler must be worthy of
the right to rule

523980EB9572462EAD797DCA6FDF8DBF.description: Explain historical philosophies of government, giving examples from world history:

952A4AB97B0E419B8F952D3A58B401E6.description:
Identify the origins and the ideals of the European Enlightenment, such as happiness,
reason, progress, liberty, and natural rights, and how intellectuals of the movement (e.g.,
Denis Diderot, Emmanuel Kant, John Locke, Charles de Montesquieu, Jean-Jacques
Rousseau, Mary Wollstonecraft, Cesare Beccaria, Voltaire, or social satirists such as Molière
and William Hogarth) exemplified these ideals in their work and challenged existing
political, economic, social, and religious structures

62A19B164A2B4DD9942CB83ABA3A4362.description:
Map the extent of the Ottoman, Chinese, Portuguese, Dutch, Spanish, and British Empires in
the 17th century and research and report on an account of travel, trade or diplomacy of the
17th century.

5FA4D4EFB16E4632BBF66B654A49DC43.description:
Identify the major economic, political, demographic, and social effects of the European
colonial period in the Americas and the Caribbean Islands, the so-called “Columbian
Exchange” (the transmission of foodstuffs, plants, bacteria, animal species, etc., across the
Atlantic for the first time and its environmental and agricultural implications); the impact of
Christian missionaries on existing religious and social structures in the Americas, and the
expansion of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.

2960C17C9C134C6AB26377EB07C143A4.description: Explain the motivations for European nations to find a sea route to Asia

E1627FFA3FF44557A6AAF37629DF3C97.description:
Describe the expulsion of Jews and Muslims from the Iberian Peninsula after the Treaty of
Granada (1492), the rise of Spanish and Portuguese Kingdoms, the Spanish Inquisition, and
the Spanish expeditions to conquer and Christianize the Americas and the Philippines, and
Portuguese conflicts with Muslim states.

C902F0D40FBF47EAADE3CFC46FE2745B.description:
Summarize how the scientific method and new technologies such as the telescope and
microscope, led to new theories of the universe; describe the accomplishments of at least
two figures of the Scientific Revolution (e.g., Nicolaus Copernicus, Galileo Galilei, René
Descartes, Johannes Kepler, Robert Hooke, Antoni von Leeuwenhoek, Isaac Newton, Carolus
Linnaeus); explain how advances in shipbuilding contributed to European exploration and
conquest.

9ED067E83B4B4EDAAB1E17397A392CA6.description:
Explain the emergence of a wealthy Protestant middle class in the 17th century Northern
Europe, its involvement in global trade, and its patronage of the arts and sciences

856CF029D27D40168AABD7A3D80C36BE.description:
Identify the role that the Protestant Reformation and Catholic Counter-Reformation played
on shifting political power in Europe, the persecution of religious minorities, and wars
among European nations in the 15th and 16th centuries CE.

964D17C055364A8AAB8050591AEA752B.description:
Explain the purposes and policies of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, including the
influence and ideas of Ignatius Loyola.

84DA7DE16A7F42188D688A4FA8FB0266.description:
Describe the political and religious origins of the Protestant Reformation and its effects on
European society, including. the reasons for the growing discontent with the Catholic Church;
the main ideas of Martin Luther and John Calvin; the importance of Gutenberg’s invention of
the printing press and its adoption by others in the spread of Protestantism across Europe, and
the formation of the Anglican Church

FF86F9E4C4A048D49392CCF944C7E996.description:
Describe the origins and development of the European Renaissance, the emerging concept of
humanism, and the influence and accomplishments of key artists, writers, and inventors of the
Italian and Northern European Renaissance.
Clarification Statement: Students may use the following examples to meet this Standard:
Italian Renaissance: Michelangelo Buonarroti, Leonardo da Vinci, Raphael, Niccolò
Machiavelli, Filippo Brunelleschi
Northern Renaissance: Jan van Eyck, Albrecht Durer, Pieter Bruegel the Elder, Hieronymus
Bosch, William Shakespeare, Erasmus, Johannes Gutenberg

4376DD9ED6F74BAA9256B219215D50AD.description:
Describe the importance to India’s medieval economy of textile technologies (e.g., processes to
improve the growing, processing, spinning, weaving, printing, and dyeing of cotton), and the
importance of cotton cloth as an export to Africa and Europe

0110095472F84B618B005E1A2A05E679.description:
Analyze the Agricultural Revolution (Arab or Green Revolution) in Africa, Europe, and Asia,
including the diffusion of plants from Asia and Africa into medieval Spain and the construction
of large-scale systems of irrigation (e.g., canals, windmills, and aqueducts).

0DC54192BEBF4A7E97485D6DDEB90BBF.description:
Explain the global spread and consequences of Chinese inventions and technologies (e.g.,
gunpowder, the compass, printing, and papermaking).

B00ADA0A1F4A4879B5DB819EBDB03BF7.description:
the development of Islamic and European universities from the 9th to the 13th
centuries

066651FF215F40569D5BC305B4D1E49E.description:
the role of Islamic scholars in preserving Greek, Roman, and Arabic texts after the
collapse of the Roman Empire and the role of Christian monasteries housing libraries
and making manuscript copies of Christian and pagan texts

D48DBECF3B6C4B6491A89A5C08A1A635.description: Explain how classical learning survived into the medieval world.

FCE026044730448689B22A159316CE25.description:
Philosophy, the arts, science and technology c. 1200 to
1700

EE3D3B480AEC4ED2A2B75A03BAC3159E.description:
Explain the global consequences of diseases, focusing on the Bubonic plague and its spread
through the Eurasian and African trade routes several times, in particular the severity of the
impact of the disease on mortality rates in Europe, Africa, and Asia in the 15th century CE.

DFFB4720CDAD49E68F9D4469FA21BD3F.description:
Evaluate the causes, course, and consequences of the European Crusades in the Mediterranean
region in the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries CE.

54A144B04D274B72BCF2631BF45E95D5.description:
Explain the consolidation of wealth of the Catholic Church and the power struggles within the
church in the 11th century CE, the development of the practices of feudalism, knighthood, and
chivalry in Europe, and the emergence of the concept of rights in England.

1006A88A15F840FC9F847D85A1E0BDB8.description:
Describe coexistence, tolerance, and trade between Arab and Christian kingdoms in the 8th to
early 10th centuries CE.

8AFE19915AC14D49A7B8ABCE2D766D6B.description:
Explain the widespread practice in Europe, Africa, Asia and the Americas of enslaving captives of
war and of buying and selling slaves from the 5th to the 18th centuries CE.

A05D3D9B056B4E5490F906DFC06D9D2A.description: Explain how travelers’ accounts and maps contributed to knowledge about the world.

26B7C88F2E4248E6817F513622291894.description:
Describe the goods and commodities traded east, west, north and south along the Silk Roads
connecting Europe, Africa and Asia, including horses, grain, wood, furs, timber, spices, silk, and
other luxury goods

FECF781E7F3F42D59870F9A402358E09.description:
Italian city-states such as Venice, Milan, Florence, and Genoa (c. 800–1500 CE), the
development of banking, capitalism, education, patronage of the arts, commerce with the
Byzantine and Ottoman Empires and Asia

665F854B7446424793CCA9300A402C6D.description:
Kingdoms and feudal societies in England, France, Germany, Rome, the Netherlands,
Russia, and Spain, including the Holy Roman Empire (c. 5th century–1492 CE)

AE7A57C19AA34AB9AED1B081DA1AD7CF.description:
The Inca regional empire (c. 13th century–1572 CE), extensive networks of roads,
conquests of neighboring states, monumental architecture at sites such as Machu Picchu
and Cusco

2E7B3CB52AF643C4ADB7C8BC933026BE.description:
The Aztec regional empire (c.1345–1521 CE), the capital of Tenochtitlan, conquests of
neighboring states, monumental sculpture

C1211DCEB1044320896BCDB174B84D82.description:
The Mayan civilization of the Classic period (c. 250–950 CE), cities such as Teotihuacán,
Tikal, and Copán, pyramid building, long-distance trade between inland sites and sites
near the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean

2B868522E8264BF9BBFBD905A466D020.description:
The early period of the Mughal Empire in India (1527–1857 CE) and its development as a
major textile, shipbuilding, and firearms manufacturer and exporter and a major center of
illustrated manuscripts

F631B302F23945D5BE035992051CE98C.description:
The Kamakura Shogunate (c. 1185–1333 CE) in Japan, feudal military rule, invasions of the
Mongol Empire, restoration of temples destroyed in war, Buddhist sculpture, calligraphy
influenced by Zen Buddhism

39EA5DCE4C944491B6B446585C8D5940.description:
The Ottoman Empire from its beginnings in 1299 CE, its capture of the city of
Constantinople in 1453, through the reign of Sultan Süleiman I (1566 CE)

19ABC16A563B47F9A87778B7984AD154.description:
The Mongol Empire (1206–1368 CE), its role in the Silk Routes, the rule of Genghis Khan
and Kublai Khan, contacts with Europeans, and the cultural achievements of the Yuan
Dynasty (1221–1368) and early years of the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644) in China

A6DF3D8EDCAC4BF1B6AD404EEE05FAF3.description:
the Song Dynasty in China (960–1279 CE), the development of the concepts of the scholar official, landscape painting and calligraphy, and the merging of Buddhist, Taoist, and
Confucian beliefs

CA61BB508A9640EF9268FFB2EC2EB004.description: the East African Sub-Saharan kingdoms of Axum (c. 100–940 CE) and the Swahili city states (c. 8th–17th centuries CE)

A96291BA3C24490D91FF671BEF952DEE.description:
the West African empires of ancient Ghana (c. 700–1240 CE), Mali (c.1230–1670 CE), and
Songhai (15th-17th centuries CE), the importance of Timbuktu as a center of trade and
learning, the gold-salt and slave trade

081AE1FFCF1D4D88AB9CEEAA6258F187.description:
Map the geographical extent of one of the following kingdoms or empires; explain its central
political, economic, cultural developments and its role in trade, diplomatic alliances, warfare, and
exchanges with other parts of the world. (Africa, Asia, America, Europe)

0B67DEBE2A92462EA55FF00116069B25.description:
Explain the concepts of hereditary rule, kingdom, empire, feudal society, and dynasty and explain
why these concepts are important in the analysis of political power and governments in different
historical periods and in different places.

B92BA0F9165C4A2E98396E218A3A96D8.description: Interactions of kingdoms and empires c. 1000–1500

783093EF871E42F4A747271509BDEA09.description: the Abbasid Caliphate in western Asia and North Africa (750–1258 CE) and the flourishing of Islamic arts, science, and learning

E1044B1C7A4940FEB0968721C3CBF0FE.description: the early period of the Byzantine Empire (4th–6th century CE), the founding of Constantinople, the adoption of Christianity as an officially sanctioned religion, the building of the Hagia Sophia, and the development of the Code of Justinian

C2CFA622FCC6409386F8ABB8990C9652.description:
the Kushan Empire (c. 1st–5th centuries) with its fusion of Greco-Roman and Buddhist
culture and imagery in Gandharan sculpture; the Gupta Empire (c. 320–600 CE),
uniting multiple kingdoms of North, Central, and Southeast India, religious tolerance
for Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism; highly developed Hindu and Buddhist
sculpture and literature

058795BCEDCB4F4E8C1C6AFCF62FE676.description:
Locate on a map and analyze relationships between political power, religion, and cultural
achievement in one empire that flourished between c.100 and 1000 CE.

E10EA3D0256541F28DAAFDE5D20A98CF.description:
Describe indigenous religious practices in Africa and explain how these practices survived and
shaped African Christian and Islamic religions.

E8F186C206964CA98E2654B18D352565.description:
Describe the historic commonalities among monotheistic religions (e.g., Zoroastrianism,
Judaism, Christianity, Islam) and how they differed from polytheistic religions.

B15CC80226D14FC79565B689F7BD8687.description:
Describe the central tenets of Hinduism, Judaism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Christianity, and
Islam; create a timeline that shows when and where each religion or belief system began.

FE3FBF93C41E4AD2BD7F88FC07E01DDF.description:
Map how the Buddhist, Christian, and Islamic religions spread from their places of origin to
other parts of Eurasia and Africa to c. 1400 CE, and explain some of the means by which
religions spread

82941DBFB4C349428C3E421BC8C9AD65.description:
Development and diffusion of religions and systems of
belief c. 500 BCE–1200 CE

E643B43C4EFA409CB1F723D2EDA41646.description:
charts or graphs to convey comparative information (e.g., size of population in different
periods and places, value of goods traded between different locations)

B854AD9382734FCA851B3ED0E42CAEBD.description:
timelines that show simultaneous relationships (e.g., the development of technologies
or artistic styles in different parts of the world or the rise, interaction, and collapse of
multiple kingdoms or empires)

CC4DB95DCE8E41A294C941819969FD28.description:
different kinds of maps to show physical features, political boundaries and forms of
interaction (e.g., trade routes, invasions, cultural diffusion)

4EC2598FC7434D2E9B517C940F65FBDC.description:
Demonstrate the ability to construct graphic displays that convey information about interactions
among and comparisons between societies

33F256BD3A084319923D8707DA1E7434.description:
Demonstrate the ability to analyze primary sources, including texts, maps, diagrams, works of art
and architecture

062A08C8FAEE4861802D9EF715E87666.description:
Explain how interactions among societies are affected by geographical factors such as the
location of bodies of water, mountains, and deserts, climate, the presence or scarcity of natural
resources, and human factors such as population size and density, mortality rates, or migration
patterns.

CD5E4D09CDCD40D7B872350B8416C095.description:
Give examples of exchanges of ideas and goods among ancient complex societies to c. 500 CE.
Clarification Statement: As a reminder of concepts studied in grades 6 and 7, teachers
may choose to highlight topics such as the spread of agricultural practices, the adoption
of religions, imperial conquests, or the first phase of trade along the Silk Roads among
societies in Asia, Africa, and Europe.

0ABE7C72C9244F3B89FFEB50BEF8CE56.description: Dynamic interactions among regions of the world
